Praefatio.	Introduction.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After having completed this book for you, which is the last scientific work on medicine in Arabic along with its complement, and being led to a conclusion of it as I proceeded through their explanations and declarations - all that has been done so far concerning your complete satisfaction regarding this Treatise specifically pertaining to surgery.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with hands has prevaclty established itself in our region and at the time of my writing (it is possible that this science may even perish): until perhaps such an investigation into it will be lost: nothing remains from these except descriptions found among ancient books, which had their pages torn away by hand; errors occurred to them as a result, resulting ultimately in incomplete intentions on his part and elongated replies. I see myself obliged to perform this treatise according to the manner of its presentation, including forms of cautery knives and remaining instruments for surgical operations: also taking into account additions made by him out of declarations therein which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Because a good surgeon cannot be found in our time using his own hands: for the art of medicine is long and requires an author to exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy which was narrated by Galen; until he fully knows how members are formed, their connections, separations, bones' structure, muscles’ form, fowl limbs if any (since some birds possess them), scales' number and arrangement on these parts along with other details concerning the exit of blood from vessels thereof.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because it was said by Hippocrates that the name of this treatise is much but its work only little: and especially so with regard to surgery which pertains chiefly to hands' skill.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already told about that thing at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For those who are not skilled in anatomy that we have told about it is no longer sufficient; since as they destroy human beinings from errors which happen when these people act without knowledge and science: I myself saw many of such people coming, bearing themselves with their ignorance on this subject, lacking any scientific education or experimental practice.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Which is so that I saw a foolish physician follow up with scrofulous swellings on the neck of a woman and incise some arteries in her throat: blood flowed from this woman until she died between his hands. The sentence describes an unconventional, unscientific medical practice observed by someone who considers themselves to be learned. It criticizes the physician for engaging in such treatment without knowledge of medicine or science and lacking experimental methodology. This suggests a historical context where superstition influenced some forms of medieval healing practices rather than evidence-based approaches that we associate with modern medical treatments, reflect
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician who dares to extract the stone from a man's body that he was processing during his lifetime and whose boulder-like stones were large. This passage highlights extreme treatments of medical conditions in history, such as urolithiasis or urinary calculi, where invasive procedures like lithotripsy (stone removal) might have been
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore I went to him and extracted it with a crescent-shaped blade. This sentence refers to an invasive procedure carried out by the physician for removing something (likely kidney stones) from inside someone using
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And why did this man expire on the third day? The shortened text prompts inquiry into a case where an individual unexpectedly passed away
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I have already spoken to remove it myself and saw that the size of its stone was great along with a certain positioning or condition of his body which causes death: This passage suggests an observer's (likely non-medical) involvement in performing invasive medical procedures, indicating historical practices where laypeople attempted surgeries without professional knowledge. It criticizes such interventions as they were not only futile but also harmful
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another physician who accepted the stipend from some of our dukes concerning medicine and happened that a black eunuch was at his side when he fractured his leg near the ankle: The observer notices how, despite their ignorance, they wrapped the injury tightly with bandages soaked in saliva (poultice), applied leeches to draw blood from various parts of him and used strong binding for immobilization. Moreover, he did not release his suffering until death took its course: This passage presents a critical viewpoint on historical medical practices that were primitive at best. It describes the harsh treatments with no understanding or success—using saliva as an antiseptic (though it would have had some limited benefit), employing leeches for bloodletting to cure without any scientific basis, and physically restraining a patient severely while attempting non-evidenced healing methods. This reflects the medical ignorance of that era where even practitioners lacked proper knowledge about body anatomy or effective treatments. The eunuch's fracture was treated without any modern orth
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	He then released him according to his inclination.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	After that he let him go for some days and then forbade him to stretch the sinew, saying thusly; so that his leg remained unhealed until it became atrophied through disuse, and finally was lost along with its foot, leading ultimately to death.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	Therefore I called him and then showed him how it should be done; afterwards he performed the operation himself after which there was peace from pain, without his previous sufferings of grief or anguish.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the injury had already become established and could not be stopped therein within that limb.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore he ceased the wandering of decay through the body part until it expired.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced the abscess and after one day it became sore; but through his craftiness was magnified in anger towards him by his lord on that same day. This sequence of events is testament to Albucasis's detailed account, where not only medical procedures are described, but also societal interactions influenced by such occurrences during the medieval period. His texts serve as a window into both
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	What is it that when a cancerous abscess arises from melancholinally derived humors within the body, there should not be an expectation for survival upon its arrival unless there exists in some part of the body where such presence can tolerate without being expelled entirely. This statement underscores Albucasis's understanding that even life-threatening conditions like cancer could lead to death when no curative measure was effective or possible within his medical knowledge during medieval times, particularly if it caused systemic failure rather than localized damage from which recovery might be conceivable with
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason of my son's sake that you understand which operations are divided into two parts by hand division; namely the surgical procedure associated with health and the risky intervention involving multiple dispositions through instruments: a clear distinction Albucasis makes in his texts between different types of medical treatments, acknowledging both their therapeutic benefits as well as potential hazards. His approach suggests an awareness that some procedures carry inherent dangers which must be carefully weighed against the expected outcomes during this period when surgical practices were still rudimentary and often perilous without a full understanding of microbial infections, emphasizing his contribution
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have now called this book to all places where it arrived concerning surgery; a topic filled with fear and trepidation: highlighting Albucasis's intention for his texts on medicine and surgery not only as academic resources but also as guides that could confront the anxieties surrounding medical interventions of his time. His efforts demonstrate an acknowledgment of patients’
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Why is it necessary for you to cut that and cover the wound? So as not to imitate a fool who finds speech without work or deceitfulness.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Then take measurements with care and protection, and treat the sickly ones easily and firmly; continually improve your travel to receive greater blessings from God for health and an honorable legacy: relinquish terrible diseases difficult to cure by medicine alone: remove anxieties that cause fear in our bodies because it makes us hesitate before stepping onto you, the faith of which will benefit both me personally and comfortably.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For indeed it remains for the sake of honor to our bodies, and more elevated here below than anywhere else; finally at last as regards bodily proportions.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	And Galen had said some things like this already..
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not cure illness with bad medicine, nor do you seek to harm your physicians by name-calling or insults.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now this treatise is divided into three chapters..
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter one is about cautery with fire and hot metal as well as sharp tools; it details the instruments used by caulkers from head to foot and leg, their forms, and related equipment required for surgical operations..
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two., et instrumenta Cauterii: quorum in operation
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter two is about incisions and punctures; draining blood vessels (phlebotomy) as well as bleeding through other means such as cauterization or cutting of the skin with a scalpel (ventosis). It also includes techniques for treating wounds, abscesses, fractures, arrows, and similar issues. This chapter is arranged in order according to forms used by caulkers..
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three., et instrumenta Cauterii: quorum sunt ex
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Chapter three is about restorations and relocations; treatments for twisted (torsioned) wounds as well as similar issues. This chapter covers techniques from head to foot along with the forms used by caulkers..
Soli Deo Gloria.	For God's glory alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgery Book by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the incision and the removal of wounds (cauterization) that will fit with their coloration at which time for metal or gold respectively.
Caput I.	Chapter One: De Incisione Caut
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But let me also remember the surgery with this thing and its wound removal (cauterization) quality, as well as any damage done by it; so that I can show what kind of coloration will appear afterward from each one in which case metal or gold may be used.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say then that the talk about the quality of incision cautery and its wounds is a long speech filled with science and secrets known only to few experts in this hidden art.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Indeed it was spoken among that crowd of wise men and they disagreed about this; and to me insufficiently so because I fear an extension in time caused by listening too long.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say then that cautery bestows universally on all wounds (complexions) with or without matter: except for two types of complexions which are a hot complexity without any substance and a dryness-without-substance complexity respectively. This is the only universal aspect it has; therefore, I am afraid my talk was not sufficient to explain this one point fully in their presence today. They could have heard me better if they had been present yesterday when Albucasis himself spoke about such things: but since that time no man speaks as he once did and now there are some who say it is harmful, which I believe because of the suffering caused by our own cutting surger
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	Moreover, they disagreed that hot and dry complexions with matter existed too. This seems to be another point where their understanding diverged from Albucasis's teach
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	However, some said that cautery is suitable for those wounds as well. This statement reflects the disagreement and different opinions held by various individuals regarding Albucasis's methods of treatment with metal implements used to seal or close a surgical inc
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And they said that in opposition to the latter's claim regarding cautery being unsuitable for such wounds as those related by heat and dryness which are due to fire since nature is associated with warmth: thus it seems unfitting or harmful not only when there’s a hot and dry complexion, but also if one remains after the treatment of such. These were among his detractors' criticisms that Albucasis should reconsider using cautery in these cases because they believed healing was improbable due to natural laws as described by Galen himself: therefore suggesting an alternative approach more aligned with traditional treatments emphasizing non-invasive methods and the body’s innate ability to recover. This exchange highlighted a pivotal debate about surgical interventions at that time
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who speaks against his words said that by a cautery one finds relief from every hot and dry disease affecting the human body; for when you compare the human body with its moisture, as if it were fire, you find the body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I too do say through his speech that he has now left it by experiment several times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not proper that anyone should come on this unless he has already tried and practiced the cauterium operation several times in his last chapter of study regarding human complexions, diseases within themselves, their causes and circumstances as well as space and time related to such issues.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	However among the remaining human temperaments, there is no fear of steel on their bones and especially in diseases with cold and moist afflictions.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all the physicians have nourished themselves on this, and they did not differ from one another with respect to praising cautery among them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And he knows that his son was treated through the secret use of cautery with fire and its goodness overcomes it above all others in terms related to treatment: for as fire is simple itself whose action has not reached me except against the part which you have made numb by cauterization, unless harm comes from another joined body part. It does no harm when joining that other body part with this one if there's no damage caused to it.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	However the action of medicine that burns has succeeded to this extent that it extends from body parts: and perhaps even leads to occurrences within the diseased part itself which makes difficult healing, and possibly causes death as well. This is especially notable in relation with cauterization performed on bones for lengthening purposes. The physician's own action burned his son when treating a limb, resulting in difficulties of healing and possibly even causing the patient’ end life – this happened after applying treatments like those that are described within these pages
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire does not make use of its own subtlety and goodness unless it is in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	We now understand it through experiments of slender instruments and studies with the art, because of which we are exempt from lengthy speeches on matters of nature due to its shortness.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not so that we could obtain from you the hidden secret of operations concealed in fire regarding its quality with bodies which exorcises diseases through philosophy and logic demonstrated by reason to remove illness from minds, otherwise known as medical discourse. This would be an excellent way for us learn about surgical techniques without having a direct Latin text at hand!
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And the son knows that they differ on time when it is fitting to use a heating instrument and better spend words instead of using fire for curing purposes. This implies an understanding among contemporaries regarding optimal timing in surgical procedures, further highlighted by preference towards verbal communication over direct treatment methods at specific times. These insights offer fascininating glimpses into the knowledge-sharing practices within these historical
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I declare that the heating instrument is used at all times for it; therefore, because an injury occurs due to cold being exposed and attracted by fire, which ensnares with burns. This statement suggests a continuous application of heat as treatment throughout various circumstances when injuries may occur from exposure—emphasizing thermal methods over traditional care approaches within their contextual understanding in the medieval era. The mention of 'injury' here likely encompasses not just physical wounds but possibly even societal or moral harms that were thought to be alleviated
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Especially so if the heating instrument is necessary for severe pains resulting from certain diseases that do not accept delay: therefore, because it is feared of them; which happens due to greater malice than minor harm caused by delays about treatment timing in time-sensitive situations. This passage indicates a concern over patient conditions requiring immediate intervention and suggests an understanding among practitioners during the medieval period that some medical emergencies were too critical for procrastination, emphasizing rapid response despite potential risks involved with hurried actions. It illustrates how urgency was perceived to be of utmost importance when dealing with severe ailments in historical surgical practices.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And it does not fall upon the minds of sons and students who do not fear if they are ill unless surrounded by ignorant or derogatory physicians: namely those whose ailments heal through fire but never return in health again; hence, let them place their faith therein as well. This indicates that throughout history, some believed certain treatments had lasting negative effects on patients' recovery and overall quality of life—an unfortunate perception among physicians at the time regarding specific cauterization methods for treating pains or wounds caused by excessive moisture in body fluids. Such practices illustrate how misinformation could have influenced medical decision-making, reflecting a broader understanding and skepticism toward certain medieval healing techniques based on their outcomes rather than scientific efficacy.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Therefore if the patient's wound is not healed by medicine and her own efforts at treatment through medical means as well as with utmost diligence to improve his condition for lordship (mastery), it may be possible that she recovers some part of health within an hour according to the patient's constitution, location of illness, and merit: which when prepared in her body is applied by itself into wound from aggregated excretions contained therein; and having thus been introduced internally through food (or something containing it), if not made sour or unsuitable for treatment as a result of the disease.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Therefore if a painful condition underdeveloped excretions and moisture within the small limb (hand), similar to cauterization of a tooth because of suffering as well as these like it; possible is, that he does not recover in this one with such suffering.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this fits only briefly.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But indeed this is a wrong and misleading talk about the last medicine (cure), which does not intend what they think in it: for as far as these are concerned that healing should result without treatment with medicine, or later on after its use; clearly no such cure gives.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the contrary is true to his intent that cautery should be considered as medicine's last resort; for when we administered curative methods in a patient suffering from illness, and did not offer them these treatments: then we applied such therapy after medical treatment was over. When this happens, he who thinks the wrong thing about what is meant by cautery being the last medicine of doctors falls; because it does indeed belong to physicians as their concluding methodology for curing and treating illnesses when all else fails – not according to those ignorant individuals' misguided notion and belief.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But the ancients said that applying heated wires was better with gold than iron for making cuts; and they did not say this because of equality in terms of silver (gold) being superior to it, as well its sublimity itself: moreover saying that where cauterium is applied there will be no pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	It is not absolutely so: for I have already tried it and found that this alone does not produce anything without other things in certain bodies.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the scalpel is good with itself too, as some have said it is better than iron.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But nevertheless when thou burnest the scalpel with fire in gold, it does not declare thee; for as soon as it is lit by what amount of heat will be done to metal' end in tarnish: and if sufficient friction properly applied towards producing coldness after its ignition on top of that has been added a little more fuel over which liquidates into fire, and runs down into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore the artist falls from this because of it; and therefore there is a scalpel with iron among us more likely to lead towards work due to its virtue in honesty.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I myself have arranged this chapter on the scalpel from its head to its feet according to chapters, so that those seeking may find out what he wished for by it.

Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	Head XXIX. When a patient experiences pain in the epigastrium from cold and moisture, or heavy breathing until they expel excess air naturally; when this is done while taking into consideration what has been stated beforehand - it will not benefit them: then he must ensure that the sick person lies on his chest so as to cover all wounds with their own bandages, applying three cauterizations following these illustrations and quantities of ice below Epar's inferior part. When they have completed this for a distance equal to one cubit; there should be space between each caustic instrument according to the width of fingers: and it is not permitted that your hands are heavily wrapped with bandages when performing cauterization, even if several times - thus making them unable to move freely.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And it should be the amount of ice that has been accumulated to hardness in the skin; and he must keep him standing on his feet firmly grounded until health is restored.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If not lying down, then he should be sitting now; extending his legs and bending his arms as required by the situation for treatment at that time.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of a caustic operation.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed to you it may be possible that one can perform these caustic operations with a small tool like an acid needle when under your guidance and skillfulness of the craft itself.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take care of yourself so as not to undergo further cauterizations unnecessarily and with extreme pain in the skin where it is particularly fine; for you know that there - this knowledge guides us all: therefore heal your own wounds, apply ice generously until full recovery.

Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the patient's exitus occurs and you know whether it is an apostema in the heart or its tunication; if it is in the body of the heart, then there is weakness accompanied by pain without acuteness: and if it is in the tunication of the heart, with pain comes a constant uncomfortable warmth that does not cease even after medical care has exhausted their efforts.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is therefore necessary for such an indisposed patient to lie upon his own pillow.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Thereafter, designate a place of the aposteme with incision (or excision): and then make an instrument that resembles burning coal for removal or destruction.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And this is the way of incision with a single instrument until it consumes all the skin and recedes into veins (or blood vessels), so that when everything has retreated inwards to the hollows (sinuses) or cavities, then take care for an exitus from its wounds. And it must not be that this kind of cauterium (instrument) should be employed unless the study in medicine has been prolonged by him, and if you meet with such diseases at your hands as these through trial a few times: then perhaps he will dare to try this sort of operation. This is their form and method too.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	Indeed, for my part it would be better not to send that person away with such a disease (condition).

¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method for cauterizing wounds in hydropsychology.
Caput XXXIII.	Head XLIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cauterizer does not fall into hydropsychology unless it is healed internally.

Let there be thickness of cauterized areas close together under skin tension.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then let go off the open caustic to allow for discharge over an extended period.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And let not the weak patient be healed immediately after caustic treatment with such aims: which is necessary that they come together into recovery more swiftly, helped by God' endorsement.

¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	From the extraction of Sebulus from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter Eighteen begins here.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	The red-colored waxes contained within Sebulus wrap around the eye and forbid any surgical operations on it; they weaken the eyes as days pass by.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore it is necessary for you first to determine whether the eye encapsulated by Sebulus contains any other disease besides Sebulus itself; if not, then carefully gather Sebalus from that specific eye.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary for you to first make the head appear weak so as to deceive them: place your own head into theirs.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Thereafter suspend the waxes with an eye-shaped object such as a beetle or two: let them assume various shapes of their waxen capsules either by this method alone or using only one very fine uncinus which is made in accordance to its shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Thereafter carefully gather the waxes with delicate antennae like beetles or two; after exactly one hour and forty minutes have passed since you began to apply this treatment, look at your own eyes for any redness in them until they disappear: remove Sebulus by using a special tool designed accordingly. Be careful not to harm the eye itself as well as its sensitive appendages like eyelids or pupils when removing it from the socket.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your surgical procedure be carried out at midday before the sun stands directly overhead; and remain unyielding throughout this process without causing harm to anything, except for those waxen capsules as mentioned above: thus will you avoid damaging any other part of the eye.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And once you have completed this task, infuse the residual Sebulus with either sulfur or red wine to enhance its pungency and facilitate further removal of it from within itself as needed for complete eradication: thus will you effectively remove any remaining traces left by it in your eye.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If for some reason you cannot gather Sebulus from within the eye during that particular hour, then bind your eye with this substance which soothes pain in eyes; release its effects a few times throughout those days until it remains firmly affixed to itself: ensure safety against heat exposure. Repeat these steps according to the same procedure as mentioned above until healed and secure.

Short blades with hardened edges made by striking red-hot iron are used to shape the endpoints of narrow grooves and canals: they should be pointed or rounded at their extremities (teeth), which sometimes serve as instruments, working on them firmly; this is done when drawing tight strings in some teeth's depth without harming one’s own.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the ends are shaped like a 'cigale' (woodpecker), and they have strong contractions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	On the excision and removal of teeth, especially from the jaws where bone fragments are involved.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When there is a tooth left after excision that has fractured something, at that time it must be placed on the socket with butter and sugar in one day, or two days; then pressed into place: whose ends become like an eagle's claws (ciconia).
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	This is a form of hoof.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	The ends of those are made like fingers or talons (aliskile).
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If therefore you do not comply with the exiting of these hooves (forcæ), then it is necessary to bring down the neck over the root, and tear away all flesh from the body; thereafter insert a small lever known as Palanca parva, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Keep the exits smooth and not too rough; let there be no drinking so that it does not break (an abscess).
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If therefore the root comes out through this, it will be good; but if not, one must urge with these instruments whose forms are such as they have just described. This concludes my commentary on Chapter XXXI of Albucasis' treatise "Al-Tasrif." May your studies continue to enrich your mind and hands in the noble art of healing through surgery.

Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Even the puncture with this instrument which resembles a large horse-flesh fly and has three blades of curved edges where there is magnitude to avoid breakage, and it should not be filled.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many tools for the tooth: and similarly other instruments not counted here; nor does the skilled artisan find himself needing others beyond his own creation, according as he finds significance in its operation and afflictions.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Since from agriculture they have not been mentioned among the uses those ancient tools of which their species has diversity.

If the tooth is broken out of its socket within the jawbone or otherwise, if it' endures decay; then investigating over said with that very instrument and forceps which I have named for root extraction elsewhere in this text along with corresponding movements.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Let it be in that magnitude gradually as strings are drawn out and held together with them so the tooth is retained until withdrawal of said tooth when restoration will have place by appropriate medicine.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there be decay within the bone only slight and partial; then remove that portion with its own rot which I have named for such removal elsewhere in this text along with appropriate care until it shall recover.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of cutting edges of the teeth among others (serrature dentum)." ### Instruction: Translate the following complex medical Latin passage about
Caput XXXII.	Head III.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When the teeth do not follow their natural course but grow outwards and become painful; this is especially true when it happens to women or girls who are pregnant. In such cases of misalignment due to changes in dentofacial structure, surgical intervention may be necessary as a last resort after exhausting all conservative treatments. The procedure should ideally correct the alignment while preserving as much natural enamel and periodontal ligament attachment possible around each affected tooth for an optimal outcome of function and est

Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	Therefore, if a tooth has been born after the loss of another tooth and it cannot be located or cut with its own saw (or scalpel), then excising this itself should not take place at that time: nor is cutting away any part of such annexed tooth permissible. This form refers to.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	The skull was made from metal and has sharp edges at its ends: this is the shape.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And you should cut out of it on certain days and because of the hardness of teeth: so that no other tooth will be dislodged.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If then a prominent ridge is exposed on your tooth: at that time the edge of this should be cut with its own instrument, which form it takes.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Cut the tooth entirely out and with a small-sized cutting edge of instruments like knives or scalpels (similarly shaped as wires): then cut it gradually over several days for ease, so that no other tooth will be dislodged: after this remove softened parts together with some abraders.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If however the tooth is broken and causes pain in the tongue: at that time it should be cut back as well with its own instrument until smoothness of rough parts has been removed on both sides so they cannot hurt again.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On extracting the tooth with gold wire: 
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	Whenever there is concussion and motion of the anterior teeth due to percussion or other causes that it cannot be firmly grasped with what you use for chewing (bite-worn restoration) so as not to fall: then apply medicaments suitable for stopping bleeding, but no treatment should take place at this time. The skill in such matters is using the gold wire because of its strength and resistance from corrosion after a few days:
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let there be a thin thread finely woven and coarsely made according to its proportion which will fit between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of tooth setting is that you receive a thread and insert two halves thereof between healthy teeth: then move one or more threads with their extremities among the teeth, if possible without pain until completion reaches another safe side of a healed tooth through the use of the filament.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then continue to apply the texture until you reach where you first applied it; and pull with your hand using subtlety and wisdom, so that it does not remove too much: and let there be a restriction of thy thread pulling at the roots of the teeth, as being against decay.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then incis the superfluous ends of threads with forepaws; and gather them together along one side or both sides alternately until they come to rest securely, taking care not to harm your tongue: then withdraw so strictly that it remains only while there is something left hanging between a healthy tooth.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it breaks or comes off, then pulls them with another thread in the same way for as long a time as necessary.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of teeth and figures regarding tooth setting for two healthy teeth which will move about like eyesight.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it happens that one tooth falls out or two are extracted from their places and return in different positions as we have described them; they remain hanging by the roots at rest: but this is not done unless there is a skillful maker of teeth, prudent and expert.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when someone is suitably prepared from bones or ivory; it takes the same shape as a tooth and is set into its place whereby the decayed tooth was removed being fastened with thread: so that, remaining in this manner for some time longer while tied together by their roots they continue hanging there. But if someone does not know how to perform these things correctly or safely then he should be excluded from performing dental work on living people and animals since it is dangerous for patients as well as owners of the teeth when performed incorrectly, because untrained individuals may injure a patient by accidentally pulling out healthy teeth instead.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On cases where an incision has occurred under the tongue and forbids it.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Whenever an incision occurs under the tongue it is either natural, as in where man originates from or due to some unfortunate incident that has already occurred.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation is that it opens your infirmity' end mouth into its hollow and lifts up the tongue so: thereafter incises this nerve ligament through the width until the tongue detaches from holding onto itself.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there were something hard and knotty within it; and if that had occurred because of the consolidation of an injury: then you would thrust in a hook into it through its width until reaching that ligament until hitting upon those nodes which are thus loosened by tearing.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And take care not to create a deep wound within the flesh; and thrust an arrow into it thereafter blood flows out of it..
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Therefore he dips to examine the wound with rose water, vinegar or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then he places a linen cloth under the tongue that holds an ill person throughout every night so it does not get better again..
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If blood flows forth, then he places a clod of earth over the place where the wound is..
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If then the blood pursues you, thereafter with a slow-burning brand of dark freckle skin used for that purpose; afterwards take care about it together with other remaining treatment until healed..

Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV..

Whenever an abscess occurs beneath the tongue which is similar to a frog's skin and forbids its natural movement; sometimes it even becomes so large that one must open the mouth until exposed..

This is the form.

When you then speak that language to it and show your poisoned state: and let the creature fall on top of its own use (to die), take a hook, insert into its tonsil, and pull out something from beyond its entrails; as much as can be taken outside with teeth after having torn flesh off their tunics.

They are assimilated by flies; however, their extremities should be crushed so that the opening at each end is sharp and directly opposite another one (which resembles a needle). If blood flow occurs, gargle with the solution in which crushed granules of thyme are found or similar herbs from a saline mixture until the bleeding stops; then take care of it until healed.

Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And indeed I have already medicated a woman who was born between the twin canals in an apostema; which drew blood towards her nose and thus pressed against it - she had little sensation because of that: at least this has been partially closed by my mouth, as she breathed through me now, no longer allowed to lie down on pillows or lay back off a bed. If there's not enough water for the next day too (if we talk about survival), I will be dead in one day or two days.:
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And only the apesasthma arose that which had relieved with twin branches until they emerged from above two nasal openings.:

Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then having removed it from where there was an opening of a nasal passage..:

Then I opened his/her mouth and pressed the tongue of her; then fastened a thorn to its apostema: afterwards having removed that part from it, he/she did not run away until there was little blood left in him/: hence is established therefore being cleaned out by gargling with water (from eating), beginning immediately to drinking liquid::after which had been taken food..

Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	Therefore, I therefore caused to burn the ulcer between my teeth.

¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	Concerning the cutting of an ulcerated hard stone.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter thirty-seven.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When the goiter descended to a neck and it swelled up, then that was an apostema; which lasted for some time, at such times when its name itself is appropriate: and if in its lower part there were both thickness and round-shaped form present, by those alone would I call this ulcer uua.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated as described before with him who divides and does not confer treatment; when you see that the hot ulcer has cooled down from herbs applied to it, then one must cut into it therewith: for at those times such an apostema should be incised.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which is attached to it and not its length; neither of the three colors—blood-redness or blackish or dark gray—nor touch sense thereof, at those times one must cut into this: for when such an apostema should be incised.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For fear of the weak in it is contained within that.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Therefore one should make a hole with the hook and pull it through; then cut backward into that hard ulcer, using two instruments used for cutting as I described before about halving palatine tonsils: and this is how to treat an apostema on horses or oxen.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And one must not cut into it unless that which adds is placed upon the natural end without adding: and when this has been done, then place a piece of bark or rope about its mouth—or if you prefer to use skin as in my case (because I have no flesh), stretched over some firm
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	Therefore if I cut from that more, it brings voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Therefore after describing the operation of cutting out two stones from a tooth cavity as we narrated previously and taking care until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the sick person falls from this incision, it is then necessary for you to use your intelligence without fear or timidity for his cauterization.

¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On the excision of a swollen lump:
Caput XLV.	Chapter forty-five.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of goats and I have already divided all their species as follows; it is necessary that someone should understand the difference between a Goat [Nodrum] and an Exitor.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I declare that when the Exitor is heat, fever, and painful sensations which are violent until excessive boiling overflow occurs leading to decomposition; then indeed disease rests in repose.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the Nodrum is not heat, nor fever, nor painful sensations and contains these calming medicines contained within its own sac: which in color corresponds to that of a person's body; likewise it mimics both Cicer (chickpea) and Batecha.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are two in kind:" either moist or dry.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of this moisture vary according to what I have divided.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary then that as you approach the cure of Nodes (goats), so learn to observe it and investigate this immediately with a tool which I call Intromissus, according to what follows after here.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the mode of inquiry is as follows for all Nodes (goats): so that you will receive this tool and place it in a moistened region which you find to be an apostate: then with your fingers, slowly digging into this gradually until you know when already penetrates through skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Thereafter measure the last hand according to the magnitude of the Apostate (goat).
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Afterwards remove the Intromissus and observe what it leaves behind on examination.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If then it withdraws a running moisture with any such colour thereat; the same dry material shall be cut out superficialely following what I have said concerning other Apostates (goats).
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if moisture does not come out during probing of the abscess Intromissi then you know that it is filled with pus: dry therefore take over its top surface in a cruciform shape (as shown to you), holding an unguent, and spread this widely on the skin covering the lesion all around uniformly; afterward remove by rubbing or scraping away as much of the crusty substance from every part of it carefully: hold kistin if possible over that so as not to draw out foreign matter but only pus (with Nodo).
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the pus discharges during operation and it is not possible to remove the abscess cleanly then often this happens: cut off part of it externally until nothing remains except for something inside which may still be infectious (with Nodo).
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	Because if any foreign substance remains within it more or less the size of a pea, then frequently returns with nodule (with Nodo).
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if you are harmed by it and there remains within a little piece of foreign material: immediately cleanse this thoroughly with some saline solution (or similar), corrode superficially the wound area using one or more sharp needles which have been heated in hot oil until they become red, tie off securely at its upper end where it is hanging abnormally and place a warm poultice on this point; keep observing till it becomes healthy again (with Nodo).
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then the nodule is large and has two lips around: carefully remove both with a gentle scooping instrument (or similar), being cautious not to cause unnecessary pain or injury; apply dressings that are moistened in wine vinegar, allowing them themselves to be infused into wound surface which becomes
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if you find that your pulse is contrary to what I have said or not pulsatile at all: promptly apply pressure, mark the area with ink where this occurs and release it slowly over two days, three days, until the abscess discharges its own matter; then return for a new examination of whatever remains from Nodo.

And the ends which are sharp for incision become pointed and blunt: while others remain not pointy except when they make an incision necessary to remove a nodule at fear of it being cancerous, or tumor in lymph nodes, etc.: so that through this one becomes healthier afterward; thus escaping the burning caused by abrasions on these. Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of silver, and they resemble glass from which is derived alcohol; at the end there is a hole discreetly drilled for bone: through this flow blood internally and externally when urged by drink.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of the bone which hides among fingers at an aperture is disguised by small nail-shaped projections; it does not affect them and they are three species in size: great, middle, and little.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the winds which cause blood to stop flowing are: great, medium, and small - they form three species in size: large, middle, and little.

And you must have these large and small species of winds at your disposal - through them remove the blood when necessary and then use it as required by need: but if for some reason medicine is not with you, do so accordingly (as one would in ancient times).
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use them for the removal of blood in any part of the body - only when it is needed from meats such as frog legs, chest, back leg muscles, and mammillary parts (like breasts), etc., which are moistened.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam. ¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the care for breasts, which resemble those of women (breasts).
Caput XLVII.	Head forty-seven.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of men are inflamed near their bedtime until they resemble women's breasts, and there remains a persistence of passionate emotion in them (that is, when male mammillaria begins to grow while he falls asleep).
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever therefore detests that, it is necessary to cut the breasts with a moon-shaped knife (that follows this shape), first along one edge and then entirely removing them in their form (with reference to line b., parallel to line g.). Next proceed by scraping off all of the remaining skin.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Thereafter they are applied with a poultice made from embalming materials.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then two wounded lips of the wound and sew them together while taking care for it until healed. 
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If the nipple declines to his lower region and becomes soft because of its size, as it happens with women: then they must be sought in two upper corners each having a moon-shaped cut (one side contains while on the other), until there is one bigger line containing smaller ones; following this shape along lines b. ad lineam g.. After scraping off what lies between those lips and taking away all remaining pinguedinum, apply as before for sutures and drugs necessary in healing (as previously mentioned). Until it has healed. 
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If it does not require you to make an incision into what is necessary for him: because of the patient's restlessness or due to bleeding from blood vessels (that remaining in a swelling formed by leprosy), then apply immediately with a scalpel cut and immerse his wound, covered entirely under corrosive ointment; let it come off until that which remains has been dissolved out of the pinguedine. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Thereafter take care for it till healed (that is). 
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Concerning the incision of a wound that happened under titillicus; 
Caput XLVIII.	Head 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	This appendectomy that occurs under Tilikli contains stones made of hard stitchworts which contain worms and from them are those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore those which contain moisture should be removed as moonstones with the following form: from line b to line g along a horizontal axis, and then is completely cleansed inside of it like something old-fdependent till another day comes.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Thereafter the belly will be taken away and cleansed with an appropriate ointment until it is healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the appendectomy was from some kind of wood-nuts or stitchworts stones, then cut over it as we previously instructed for cutting above the Strophula to an equal extent.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If the wound has extended so that it is leaking pus, then apply a heated instrument to it as we previously instructed for such situations.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the appendectomy which occurred because of artery and vein issues, follow these procedures: firstly remove all foreign objects that may block blood flow; then make an incision at least three fingers'
Caput XLIX.	Head 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is disrupted and the skin above it becomes consolidated, often an appendectomy occurs due to this injury; similarly, when a vein is also injured, such as during its course through or into the appendix, which can lead to inflammation that may necessitate removal. 
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is recognized that an apoplectic state and inflammation are caused by Arteries and Veins are these; for when they occur due to arteries, there is a swelling deep in the body: And when applied externally causing spasms in your fingers or limbs, one feels as if it were stridor.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to veins, the swelling appears on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the cutting on this apoplectic condition is a mistake and especially when it occurs under the skin, groin, abdomen (belly), and other locations throughout the body; it is large ulcersation.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, its care must be treated with iron and what is also found at the ends (extremities) or on top of the head should likewise receive attention.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore over that which comes from the artery'inflammation,'find it with a cut made along its length (the affected area).
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then make an incision with forceps and then the artery: remove it from its covering until found (exposed).
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus. Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema. Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.
