Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	Which if there should be an opening in the vein due to incision, then it is necessary for you to hold your hand that possible from the wound with skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Therefore continue to press under the place where you held your hand and make it pierce: let there be a double thread until it comes out from one side of the other wound.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Therefore bind with it the good ligament at both ends of the wound as I told you to use for the bandage: let there be thread from two sides and their edges on one end only, forming a double loop around it when done so that if removed no part is left behind.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If the thread is removed from beyond that point, then immediately press again with another strand of thread undernethyel other wound directly at the very edge near to the incision knife as I told you: pinch firmly and tie off in four places for safety when done so.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then wash out the wound at last until what is within it emerges which I told you already exist therein; then remove that surplus skin and let go whatever bandaged part is left afterward when done so..
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Therefore place the swelling thing which you have submerged into water on top of it: and apply oil thereon afterward when done so..
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Therefore give that treatment which makes sickness disappear with leeches and ointments until he/she is well when done so..

¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning cutting away an evil worm found between the teeth.,
Caput LI.	I've completed translating your medieval Latin text
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	They affect some men many times within their teeth and throughout the remaining parts of their bodies, which are called by a name resembling mushrooms..
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Of such roots is one delicate and of the other its head large; their lips are turned inwards..
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it comes from among them, an evil worm that grows very big.: And is found also within those who swallow the magical drug..
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have seen a man, and within his teeth there were two such worms, which are bigger than other things like mushrooms: but the difference between them was not apparent to me in colour or size of roots.; Neither had any visible differentiation; they even turned their lips towards each other as if intending exchange..
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I cut it thusly; I found its weight to be nearly ten and eight-tenths of an ounce on one side and six-tenths of an ounce on the other: then, perform incision into those parts which you find moist at this time with white coloration underneath a fine root. Then cut it inwardly along these lines upon their surface as they are now laid down by pressure; let your present treatments be done amidst fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Therefore often blood is thrown out at the incision of that part; if it thus injures you with much blood then burn immediately into it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a weak and cowardly patient at the time of incision with fire applied to him; then take out from leaden filament wound together in twisted form, which is described hereinbefore: by means thereof tie it up tight around that part as has been declared. This method allows for its release after two days.

¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	About the softening of skin around testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter fifty-eight.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius. Therefore it is necessary for him who asks for this treatment to lay the weak body on his back and make an incision over all that has been softened by nature itself.

Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then make an incision between the stitches.

¶ De Castratione.	Chapter on castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter fifty-nine. In this chapter, describe procedures for
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	Chapter fifty-nine. In this chapter concerning castration which we have excommunicated according to our law and that I am permitted not to remember him in my book for the sake of forgetting his deed, it is sufficient only if done out of two ways: one being an act, as a wound made with iron or other hard object; another way by surgical means. This chapter concerns remedy against harm caused by castration and its aftermath.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Who is there to know when a question arises about it (medicine) and who will learn its treatment?
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And another method is that we frequently subject some animals to castration for our benefit using this (surgery), as with asses, Hyrcanian stallions, and cats.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I declare that castration is performed in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by atrophy (cessation of function)."  
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or through a cut or incision; and also dissection.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	As for those which are subjected to attrition (cessation of function), the method is that we make an animal sit in hot water until their testicles soften and lengthen; then with your hand, they will be drawn upwards: next let them fall again by touching.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	And in castrations performed through a cut or incision, you must hold the animal and press its scrotum with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then bind the suspensorium and after drying one side of all cuts until two come out; then when they have extruded themselves afterwards you wash them both with water: but do not leave over wetness which is on top of (the wound) to sift through like flour.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better for which takes place by attrition (cessation of function): as sometimes it leaves something from the testicles, whereby desire to copulation may arise in animals.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Thereafter care one until he is cured.

Then extend it evenly and not just according to straightness; move at all sides so that the baby is born smoothly in one piece like a dog's birth where there are no crinkles on its skin: as when an animal gives birth with teeth. Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And the treatment of it is that you take a quill from either an ostrich or duck feather and harden them with force; then place this thorn over the Formicum, until blood continues to flow through small cannulae within its parts: (the patient takes medicinal baths using these materials).
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Thereafter rub his hand with the thorn until it comes out of where the formic acid is inserted into its groove; and place that back in deep skin: also remove the root of the formic acid from therein, so he might be relieved.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if a wound is seared with air or iron (or other sharp object), make it in the same manner as this one.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Place a sharp tool under the surface of cut off flesh to elevate it and facilitate understanding as well as its removal from the finger.

¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Concerning healing a head wound without bone breakage.:
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head Chapter XXXIV.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	And I said that this division of the book on healing wounds suited and was to be written as follows: And here is how they will treat their wounded with hands in conjunction with medicine supplementary.:
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore that wounds differ according to the cause of injury and also according to wherein they fall.:
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Those who are wounded oftenly may be treated like flints struck or as arrows cut open; or they might have their wounds made wider with a sword blade, or by crunching on bone, wood, stone, or spear tip: and similar treatments for many kinds of injuries.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds that occur according to the parts of the body are like those which fall on top of the head, or collarbone, chest, breast, buttocks, womb (uterus), and other similar injuries: and their counterparts in these members.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am one who reports about certain wounds to apply them reason and rule for the remaining wounded.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will start from simple wounds of the head, since we have not forgotten about those who were healed by surgeons' hands at the beginning of this chapter on treatments for various injuries.

If you managed to escape the hot sores safely, then place a poultice on it if fresh blood is present, and ensure that its air did not change; I applied for this purpose some time after: but when the affected area's air had already changed, apply an ointment until healed.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If the wound is large or if it was made by an arrow and similar: and when there are no lips to be bound with lumps together as I narrate about the stitching of their foreskins in bleeding groin wounds., but instead, binds them together directly using suture.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If the wound is found on bone and protrudes without attachment except for suction into a pad of moistened cloth as I narrate about puncture groin injuries., then proceed with an incision.

Thereafter treat the wound with medicine and restore it to flesh on a firm body part cut by skin as I instruct about puncture groin injuries., recommending foods of like substance such as heads, unleavened bread cooked until softened but still full of life.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If I find the wound is rotten flesh and it has not been attached to bone: then incise all of it and apply a dressing as per my account about puncture groin injuries., followed by cleanliness, which in Latin often meant applying fresh raw meat. Subsequently care for that area.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam. Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Which if there is a necessity to operate when it does not confer that which we have said, then burn the wound until blood ceases.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If these wounds are shallow and clean, then the treatment is simple, swift: so that as this pus spreads over them: because it solidifies before changing air.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Mode of dissection in animals.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part of the onion and two parts of dragon's blood, and three not-extinguished calf hooves: mix thoroughly a lot, and beat it; then pour over ulcers from this mixture; constrict well the good swelling until it adheres firmly to the wound properly, and coagulate with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tie that above again with pus: let go of the mass when no longer present, so as not to disturb any more ulcers while they remain even after removal.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Because it is not eradicated by medicine, until healthy again.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when it has done so by the sole of a sandal alone, at present without onion and dragon'self blood: which does one same operation in many great ulcers with its own blood, suitable to place upon them and bind tightly together that have recently bled; for this blood did not alter air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	Which if that air has been changed by the same change twice, especially when it is in summer time: then this intention of our poultice no longer suits its place; so take care with what we said before and do as follows instead to put a suitable unguent over those ulcers or make paste from barley flour made into cakes by water and honey, until emitting pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the remaining treatment so that they are healed completely.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If indeed it happens that a wound breaks the bone and is incomplete at once when I am with Galen, then from now on I will speak about the treatment of skull fractures as something which was to come forth.

¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	From a wound with a spatula.
Caput LXXXVI.	Head Chapter XXXVI.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If by striking with a sword or pestle the blood comes out and you see its depth then at that time measure it carefully..
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If therefore blood comes out of a wound and the person is weak from it then at that time you know that the wound is fatal..
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	What if the wound is not deep and it bleeds profusely with its blood? At that time do not put any hemorrhoidal drugs on it at first hour nor bandage anything so as to keep back the blood within its depth, make it return to the heart, restore health in a weak person: but place an attractive ointment there and let him see nothing of his wound for two days..
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed you do not have an ointment at hand then put into the wound a soft pad moistened with warm liquid; that which comes out of it will be unpleasant to feel: let him sleep on top of this, so as whatever accumulates in there pulls away..
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If then the wound has been there three days or more and not happening any epileptic seizures neither palpitation of heart in a bad way nor shortness of breath while remaining weak with no diseases appearing: at that time you know, it is healthy..
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Take care then and again when the wound has healed completely using bandages as well with clean linen etc., until it gets better..
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed he is cured and at that time the wound always opens then you know that a fistula has become..
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Take care of it according to its booklet.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	If the wound is from an incision or a cut and it's simple on either chest surface pectoral area or back dorsally; at that time take care of it with what has passed through stitches if large: otherwise apply some ointment to relieve swelling, pain etc. in case the wound is small..
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	If then he has made an impression into the bone and cut through it with a knife: at that moment one would ask which part is being operated upon, and to pull away those parts of the tool that have been separated from its handle if they are detached.

This instruction from Albucasis stresses the importance of using needles that strike an optimal balance between size—needing fine points for better penetration but with enough strength not to be too fragile or break easily during surgery on delicate tissues like skin, while also being robust enough when dealing with larger and harder body parts requiring forceful insertion. Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not to be that the needle appears in two adjacent parts of the cut skin by much: so as flesh does not easily pierce through and wound remains open before healing solidifies; nor should suture elongate, preventing the continuance from consolidating. Albucasis advises precision when stitching close to a sensitive area like where two pieces of skin meet at an incision site—using just enough thread for secure closure without creating excessive tension that could cause damage or delay wound healing. The goal is meticulous, minimally invasive technique promoting rapid and effective consolidation while avoiding the potential pitfalls associated with overly tight sutures such as incomplete cutaneous seal, delayed recovery due to prolonged openness of a laceration

¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Concerning care with fistulas and hernias.
Caput LXXXVIII.	LXXXVIII.

Therefore all wounds that are old and ancient, or an apostema when they come forth from the body with ulcers forming constantly emitting pus without ever abating: at such time is called universally in whatever member of the afflicted one has a fistula, we call this Zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed is according to ueritatum definition as threaded narrowing, hard and white; when not painful it has been constricted with the penis: hence this particular kind of wound they call Risati which means 'pen'. And already I had preempted division at the time when I said this wound which all sores that cannot heal and do not originate from within the flesh is caused by one thing only.'

¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Of Sinus treatment, and what kind of clyster is suitable with medicine.
Caput XC.	Chapter Ninety-Nine.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When hemorrhage occurs within some flesh of the sinus cavity, and it extends for a time until blood collection is made; then either the head turns over or pierced by instruments so that whatever lies in there comes out which was originally therein at its natural state, leaving behind an empty space as if it were water without any dissolution within itself. The skin covering this remains just like previously loosened and removed adhesive bandage; but neither corrupts nor impresses into bone or nerves, maintaining a clean place almost as being void: therefore let him be called Sinus instead of Fistula, unless the space thereof continues to expand until it causes decay in any part of these body members and then such shall bear its name for fistula.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the treatment of it is to pierce this skin as though all were pulled out in its entirety; and particularly when loosened like gauze bandage (panus), one must rely on faith that there has not been a residue left behind, because of corruption.

If you hope that the skin will still cling to it and not result from further corruption therefrom; and if flesh is thickened with decay within (caro), then care must be combined with clysters at this time as well: which concerns us concerning the Sinus.

Then if it is great and pus issuing from there gives off fetid odors; then the affected part should be washed with Egyptian clysters made of wine, oil, or honey (acetum et oleum autiniar), parts taken equally into solution: which together are boiled over fire until red meat medicines change color: and it is best to do so in swelling fullness of the milk.

And whenever you clysterize with ashes of the oven or ashes from pine woods (a poultice), and this medicine is not present to thee, then take that hot water down your throat: spit out all wood-ashes; pour over it a little warm broth made by boiling bark tree's leaves in water.

Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the mouth is already large enough, then it must be bound together with a ligature and release whatever amount of that substance enters during its use without any additional supplement.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if there is inflammation of the sinus from which it comes out (e.g., a fistula), and blood flows upwards: then dry itself into the depressed place wherein that flow occurs, so as to stop its movement downward; for when pus becomes encapsulated within that Sinus, it does not produce new tissue in that area.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	What if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus below its inferior region: then, cover that with a dressing as prepared in accordance with what enters there from the above; since when pus flows out of such Sinus, it requires material easily available and suitable according to your preparation.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Cover it with something so that nothing from the pus remains within; and receive drugs solidified as described above which are directed over signs of such discharge according to its nature.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	Extend these upon a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the width of that fabric be such as to allow complete communication with the entirety of the sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then insert it into the mouth's opening directly at that sinax point with forceps, and then gradually open the sinus passage as little as possible.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend the linen cloth over another ointment on the sore spot to match its size and place it above in a position distant from the sinus opening; so that all flow out of exit points: you should not remove the entirety unless after drinking water for one or two days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is at the mouth of the Sinus Cavity is he whose mucous membrane always discharges throughout all hours so that whatever collects therein becomes pus; and if you know whether this matter which comes from it consists chiefly, or only slightly, or not at all, of worm eggs, then [it] can be digestible, indigestible, easily treated.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And whenever considering the same place as his sinus cavity, he either does not feel pain therein or feels pain; and is paralyzed by it, or has no difficulty with it at all.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	Therefore you are led to a similar kind of treatment; and when the mucous discharge comes out through his sinus cavity opening, then know that Sinus has adhered within it or approximated its wall attachment: so he should take [it] with him in the morning if necessary (or on alternate days), change clothes for a while thereafter. Whenever feeling unwell afterwards, instead of bread rolls use another type and apply ointment to his backside area as well.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If he is able to leave the sinus after a long worm infestation [from it], then you should not despair of its attachment because his cure approaches; for there are some people among us who take time in bringing their internal generation into maturity, and from them come those acting contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If he is able to leave the sinus after having had numerous discharges of putrid (pus) from it for many days [therefore], then you know that Sinus did not have attachment therein at all, because when we consider him as a sick person with no disease in his bowels or urinary tracts.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If then Sinus' attachment remains for a long time and he does not improve but his condition gets worse over the same period of suffering [and having been ill], you should have recourse to medical treatment, that physicians make medicine in its humid substance as well as dry; like honey medicated when added topically after sinus secretions become excessive.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the greatest to last where it is cured, one receives anointed with unguentus dyafinicon and dissolves together with rose oil, and rubs over its ancient wine-like consistency into its own substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Thereafter the object is refined with it, and use itself thereof.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it makes a likeness to this operation itself when not present beforehand with the anointing of Dyafinicus oil and honeydew (mel), until reassembled inside after crushing out its contents in wine-like consistency, then use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and frankincense, and galbanum in the fullest measure; purify it with honey while over a fire until nothing is left except smoke that rises into the air.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Thereafter lay a linen cloth over it, and bind that with cords above the navel; when mingled honey which has been cooked is spread on it, until enlarged: purify this object of its species therewith, then place it upon the linen cloth again, and string up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when at times it is administered into that hood of the birthwort (asbestos), and roots of star-lily [actaea], which grow on earth; also present a larkspur: wheat bran from herbs, and centaurium.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or gathered together; and rub it with honey as related; then use the same.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the matter of the womb is prolonged and not healed by this treatment; then you know that in its depth there lies corruption (perhaps a miscarriage?). At such time as it becomes apparent whether an impression has formed into bones, or hardened muscles, ligaments: then treat with bandaging.

And I saw a woman who had the arrow stuck in her belly; and they were wounded there (on her); it remained inside of her: nothing changed on that account from what was previously arranged, neither did she find any harm to herself as a result of these operations or natural occurrences.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man who had the arrow stuck in his face; and they were wounded there (on him); he did not find much pain afterward: similarly for many others as well.` `

Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to his care for three days after he had been wounded by an arrow.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Having thus come armed with a sharp-pointed bow, I found myself in possession of arrows.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	Having thus asked her with subtlety and not feeling it myself, I indeed inflicted pain and suffering on that part of hers to the right from the gold touch itself.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped therefore for that sting at the arrow's tip.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore plastered the place where it had been injured with wax and honey confidently at my side because I believed that this spot would become a lair, and one day there should appear to me in its stead an arrowhead: but nothing of the sort happened on site. The arrow did not complete its path as expected.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore persisted in the wax plaster on it for several days and did not happen: a temporary injury was healed and remained infirm within the space of those daily hours until I felt something inside his nostril, like an arrowhead had entered that day's nasal cavity.

I thus possessed this sharp and cutting wound medicine for several days until it opened up; when I attempted to touch the arrowhead that was sticking firmly in the wood, its point became felt on my skin' endlessly repeating motions without success as healing progressed with time.

The text describes Albucasis’s patient recovering sufficiently to leave after treatment for an arrow injury. ¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Concerning the benefit of Bloodletting and caution in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	However, the quality or nature of Bloodletting and its accidents from them which requires you to consider their correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly therefore it is that which ought to be known and understood about Bloodletting not being administered except for the preservation of health, but continuance thereof, as well caution at approach onset.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that Bloodletting is to be done within the three unions which are in a finger's length namely - The Cephalicus (anatomical term), and also the Latissimus (another anatomical reference) and Fascicularis or Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that Bloodletting is to be done at the beginning of Lent over fasts on Fridays and during Easter season; in Autumn, Winter, and Spring when signs are indicative of satiation." This translates into an instruction for certain times throughout the year—particularly pointing towards periods which would have been understood as related to feasting or abundance. The mention of "Veris super ieiunium" specifically indicates Lenten fasts, a significant period in medieval Christianity
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And that Bloodletting is to be done on the first or third day after they have passed beyond three hours." This indicates a specific timeframe for bloodletting procedures based on the passage of time since food was last eaten, which may reflect an attempt at minimizing complications during surgery.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	However, the Bloodletting that is administered during sickness has not a fixed hour but when it comes convenient and necessary at night or daytime, on any given time of day, as well as throughout all times." This suggests flexibility regarding bloodletting in terms of timing within feverish conditions. It emphasizes the adaptability to patient need rather than strict scheduling during illness.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not permissible for the Bloodletting to be performed upon children until they have reached over four decades of age." This highlights ethical considerations and guidelines regarding pediatric bloodletting, possibly related to maturity or growth concerns. It sets an upper
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	And it is not to bleed pregnant women unless from the fourth month until the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	And do not blood let men who have already lived sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	And therefore if any one wishes to undergo bloodletting for whatever reason, it is necessary that his bowels be cleansed with purgatives before phlebotomy in case there are hard stools retained: so not harmful putrid excretions from the intestines do not enter into the veins principally affecting them.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	And it is not to bleed patients with recent meals or those intoxicated by wine until they have passed that.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	And do not blood let the weak person who suffers from dropsy (water retention).
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let the phlebotomy be repeated after colic pain caused by passion (in this case 'colic' can refer to intense discomfort), and in men, and spasms of urination flow; multiplication of intercourse labor workout, military exercises, manuals for slaves, fasting.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Thereafter also take into consideration the subtleness of human blood if it is thick with food and drinks, and medicine (if possible for him).
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Thereafter let the bath be introduced if not forbidden anything; or some exercise is done so that blood can subtly flow.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy in his breastbone about every third day as we have said: and make it so that by this bleeding is cured of which thing our patient suffers from those maladies which he has always suffered with (diseases) because of accidents animalibus, such as pain [from an injury], anger, fear. And all the diseases due to bodily evils, labor and punishment and surplus bile like that.

And let their presence be established with those substances from the fragrance of which customary usage among men has been accustomed to run through scent and aroma as well as pleasure, praise, and similar things in quantity.

Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Thereafter tightens the ligature with a pincer and passes it through twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis. Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio. Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is required that she who has filled up with blood should have a single extraction of her own blood to amplify the act of phlebotomy; let there be also an assistant at his side for this purpose: and in those who are weak, sit them otherwise. This protocol ensures minimal stress on patients while maintaining procedural effectiveness within traditional medical practices observed during that era. Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is required that blood must be extracted from her veins; and let there exist a tight-fitting opening or channel: for what has been previously done in phlebotomy was better administered through incision rather than by pricking, as this approach more effectively separates the vessels without causing unnecessary trauma to surrounding tissues. Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	This method of venepuncture is safe from the flow of blood and puncturing nerves; it's more praiseworthy and safer than venepuncture by cutting with width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	He had become accustomed to receiving his meals through phlebotomy; he must have the meat previously mashed and infused into water of saltbushes or millet ground with boiling water: if it is warm-cooked food, pour out some blood from him in three vessels.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If he has an icy complexion, at that time take before phlebotomy some bread previously infused with honey or sweet and fragrant syrup made of honey, mixed with the scent-bearing herbs; or aromatic syrup itself.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione. And he must carry out the rest as we separated it into sections earlier on, for phlebotomy exsuccionem.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever ends his meal by taking out the arm's blood and removing it immediately; if he had venepuncture for multiple extractions because of exsuccion, then this is a weak habit that removes his blood gradually over successive days. (Original emphasis on 'euius', which refers back to Albucasis)
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever ends his meal by taking out the arm's blood and removing it immediately; if he has strong flesh or body of such constitution that after seven hours (or nine days) from first venepuncture should be done afterwards again. (Original emphasis on 'eius', which refers back to Albucasis with respect to his robustness as a patient.)
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever intends to draw blood from his body toward the contrary side of where it declines should be discharged on the second day or third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	If the blood in someone's body is hot and yellow-brown, and it makes a fever happen: they must be discharged so that their blood can go into water one time, take out from them much of this blood, and if an apoplexy happens because afterward all phlebotomy conditions are being conserved by you (the reader), then place your hand over the course of his veins to prevent death at a stroke.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Often that happens when the bloodsucker is unaware and falls into neglect.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not permitted when one should loosen the arm and draw blood secondly, at a time when its opening (urea orifice) has already closed due to injury; for this would make an exit of difficulty such that it bursts forth with violence as soon as drawn from within by force, spreading out more quickly than usual.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Since I consider this bad medicine, release it until it can be bloodsucked secondly.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Alternatively, if the bloodsucker'deed done with that which has already clotted out of his blood at its entrance is discovered: pour something like vinegar on it to dissolve what’s stuck and then let water pass through afterwards.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place something from tarry pitch or saffron on it and apply gentle pressure until the blood leaves.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If there are ulcers present, then discharge that thing immediately and do not cover it up until the wound has healed on its own.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If there is a need to draw blood secondly and no exemption has been provided: then either suck the excessive amount of blood above that place directly or take it from another vein elsewhere through arm movement into different vessels within its entrance (urea).
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The surgeon removes the veins from both arms at a dark place, and if not found there, they are hidden because they consist of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of his bloodletting is such that he introduces a weak hand into hot water until it becomes ruddy and appears evident.

Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The fractures are diverse in nature and the forms of them many; their causes are different from one another.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	Because of a certain type of fracture which results from impact with an instrument; and the blow produces injury to all parts until it comes into contact with bone, just as axial cutting in wood: hence this is named the Axiolytic species of fractures.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Alternatively, a certain type of injury results from an implement entering and cutting into the bone; which then cuts to its face and does not penetrate further upwards: this is named as the Kalan species of fractures (Leuation). As with axial.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there are two more types of fractures: one is large and the other small in size. These include compound (commonly referred to as a "true" or open) injuries where bone fragments pierce through skin creating an
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia. Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum. Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora. ¶ De restauratione Anchae.	On restoration of the ankle.
Caput XI.	Chapter Eleven.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Uncommonly fractures occur in the bones of the ankle.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If then they fracture (bones), the bone is not broken unless it has a comminution at the extremities of them; and are cut across by length, and declined into the interior parts: and happens infirm weakness in pain to that place, and puncturing thereof with needle-points. And causes cramping (spasms) of those limbs which is broken or fractured.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius. This should be done to set the bone properly, and thus restore function.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali. If the fracture is along its length or already inclines inwardly: then apply a firm support to that limb until it prepares you for his bone's repair.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae. Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	And when they are in accord with that which applies it, continue until the tightness corresponds to equality; and command him as weakened to lie on his back or side so healthy.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet. ¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	Concerning the treatment of an unhinged joint.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	As regards the unhinged joint and shoulder joints; neither occurs except when it is a full dislocation, nor does anything similar occur to other less severely displaced or slightly relapsed ligaments that return to their original position after being moved back slowly into place with minimal force.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the unhinged joint can indeed be dissected according to four parts, as well.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	What is that because it dislocates towards the front and back?
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	And in fact most often it dislocates toward the inside; barely does so to the front or back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	And the treatment for such a dislocation towards the inside is because when you unite the injured leg with healthy one it goes further: and since its head (the joint) protrudes more than that of a sound, an injury cannot be duplicated at the knee end against this small bone which follows the heel after being pressed backward due to heat from inflammation caused by blood accumulation in cavities within tissues near skin.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	And the mark on this person' endured a dislocation to the outside because they are contrary signs of those very things; that is, such an injury occurs inwardly whereas these external symptoms arise outwardly as their opposite or counterparts due to certain causes beyond natural law. To heal and relieve
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	And the mark on his endured a dislocation to the front because it expanded its healthy leg according to complement: but this does not double without pain which is in the joint due only to natural causes; and since he was intended for walking, could not be thrown forward with ease of movement against that condition. He retains urine therein, his great toe turns outward at rest after being pressed backward as a result of heat from inflammation caused by blood accumulation in cavities within tissues near skin; and where he walks is the curling underne0f his foot on the heel over the calcaneum.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	And the sign of that which happened to him was a dislocation towards the back so that it did not expand and could not duplicate itself before even having duplicated its other foot: also his leg is shortened, and the hip joints are at their place in the Libyan region.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	Therefore this species of his backward dislocation is considered as ancient now that it has had the thing itself.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	So if you administer its reduction and let things remain as they are according to their position then there is nothing at all left in that treatment.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	Therefore it does not need for the presumption to be taken back from him.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	So in that case where another dislocation is recent and belongs to one of the four species of backward dislocations: it should be properly treated as follows - by joining up with a small ligature for instance; then stretching out its parts inside, outside too, towards each side. It may return again, but does not need an additional care.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If then this method does not return as before; at that time we should prepare a firm treatment - and stretch the leg from its lower part; either with his hands or above them by means of an upper band which fastens over it: another attends to extend his hand underneath, in such way as he inserts her own fingers beneath.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then by means of the above band is tied over his hip bone root; and holds its end with another that binds to it from an alternate one. Then in like manner they should treat other dislocations or deformities, whether forwards or backwards as stated above.

And when the displacement is to the anterior, then it must lie with its leg extended more carefully; as described on the bedside cradle above his hump (in which he also lies) and place a hand over the injured left foot of him by himself. This detailed procedure underscores Albucasis' sophisticated understanding of fracture reduction principles, where anatomical details like limb positioning are crucial for successful treatment outcomes in medieval times. The inclusion of the patient’s own resources—using his body and ties made from available materials like sinews or ropes, demonstrates a pragmatic approach tailored specifically to each individual's needs while respecting their autonomy and self-sufficiency.
